body:
I'm seeing some inconsistencies with building height. For example, One World Trade Center (1776 with spire). Empire State Building is listed at the tallest at 1238.79 (it's 1250 last I saw) and this does not seem to include 432 Park Avenue which stands at 1396 and should be the second only to One World Trade Center. I'm currently seeing that Empire State Building is the tallest tower.

Are these shapemaps / heights up to date? I see that it was last updated in April 2015, but One World Trade Center was completed well before that.

view.name: Building Footprints
view.description: Shapefile of footprint outlines of buildings in New York City.

body: Is there any manual way of changing the projection for the file? what is the current projection for the .shp file?

children.body:
The metadata is correct. Projection details below. Data can be reprojected using any of a number of software (ArcMap, QGIS).
* GEOGRAPHIC COORDINATE REFERENCE GCS_WGS_1984 
* PROJECTION WGS_1984_Web_Mercator_Auxiliary_Sphere

body:
We apologize for the late response.

@mp - We'll look into the metadata

children.body:
For anyone using R out there, make sure to set the proj4string on this dataset to: "+init=epsg:3857"
After importing it, then you can spTransform it to whatever CRS you like.

body: How do you view the GIS stuff from this site? i was expecting something i could open autocad, but it looks like there is more data available (the dbf files). also, the shape files aren't in the same syntax that i know from autocad, so i'm guessing there's a viewer?? i grabbed a simple shape viewer, but that freezes on some larger data files. i poked around ESRI, but nothing jumped out at me as a free viewer...

children.body: QGIS is free (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/).  No issues with QGIS on our larger data sets.

Dave LaShell. dlashell@esri.com

body:
I've published an online version of the corrected buildings data, you can access the REST endpoint and download JSON, etc., or access/draw features directly from this web service, http://nycgov.maps.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=6c55e9f147454830bd633d1cadd28520

Here's the description: NYC buildings downloaded from the NYC Open Data on 6/11/2014, downloaded data set called "buliding_0414.shape_webmercator." Numerous geometry errors were corrected using the ArcGIS "repair geometry" tool. One building with significant errors was removed, shapefile FID=7951, BIN=4566377, within BBL=4099850029 (downloaded data has incorrect BBL for this building, downloaded data BBL=4117250018), at address=90-39 144th Place, Queens, NY.

body:
Hi NYC Open Data, we noticed that the buildings_0414 shapefile contains numerous geometry errors. These are easily fixed using the ArcGIS "fix geometry" tool. You can run this tool manually (ArcToolbox) or within a Python script. We ran the fix and include all the geometries with errors below. Thank you, Dave LaShell, dlashell@esri.com

body: Yes, we will provide me details in the next extract. LiDAR was not used. The elevations were caprtured stereoscopically (i.e., using stereo paris).

body:
Would you mind expanding the metadata to explain how the ground and roof elevations were calculated? is the ground elevation representative of the lowest adjacent grade? is the roof elevation representative of the highest elevation? was this information derived from LiDAR? if so, would you mind referencing the source?

Thanks a lot, and please keep the good work in opening datasets.
